sp.p: So he axed for my Lady, and would not tell me what he wanted: I came with her, however, but ſhe no ſooner ſet eyes on him than ſhe ſent me out; which argufy'd no good, you'll ſay; and, before I could poſſibly come back, though I ran as faſt as ever my legs could carry me, he was gone, and ſhe writing and crying for dear life;—but that was no news, ſo I did not mind it: and, when ſhe gave me leave to go to the play, thought no more harm than the child unborn.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: It muſt be a ſcheme beyond all doubt, and I am the dupe of a diſſembling, ungrateful—oh Cecilia! (throws himſelf in a chair)

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: (Softening her voice and ſetting her dreſs) If I was as you, Sir, I would not fret about her:—there is not a lady in the land would ſlight a gentleman ſo handſome and ſweet temper'd—I ſcorns to flatter, for my part.—Inferials muſt'nt direct their betters: but, had I been in my Lady's place, a King upon his throne would not have tempted me.—Handſome him that handſome does, ſay I; and I am ſure you did handſome by her; for, if ſhe could have eat gold, ſhe might have had it.—He might take ſome notice truly

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (Starting up) Where was ſhe writing?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: In the little drawing-room, Sir.

This ridiculous love turns peoples brains, I think.—I am ſure, I ſaid enough to open his eyes:—but, maybe, I don't look ſo handſome, becauſe I am not ſo fine.—Hey,—a thought ſtrikes me! my Lady is gone, that's plain.—Back ſhe will not come, is as plain.
(Gathers together Cecilia's elegant clothes.)
I'll put on theſe, and he'll think ſhe gave 'em to me:—then he may find out, I am as pretty as ſhe: if not—he and I are of very different opinions. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Cruel, ungrateful, barbarous girl!—to forſake me in the very moment I was reſolving to ſacrifice ev'ry thing to her!—but 'tis juſt.—Firſt dupes to the arts of man, the pupil ſoon knows how to foil him at his own weapons.—Perhaps the diſcov'ry is fortunate. In a ſhort time, I muſt have borne the whole diſgrace of her ill conduct, and my father's reſentment had the bittereſt aggravation.—But, is ſhe indeed gone? and will continual to-morrows come, without one hope to render them welcome?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Villain! where's your Lady?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: 'Las a deazy, how can I tell, zur?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Where are all your fellows?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Abroad, meaking halliday.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: When did you go out? who gave you leave?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: My Leady, her own zelf; and I'll tell you how 'tware.—After dinner I geed her a noate; and, when zhe had red un, zhe axed me if zo be as how I ever zeed the lions? zoa I told her noa; nor nomour I never did.—Zoa zhe geed me half a crown, and bid me goa and make myſelf happy. I thought it ware deſprate koind of her; zoa I went and zeed the huge creturs; and ater, only ſtop'd a bit to peap at the moniment, and hay my fortin tould by Conj'rer in the Old Bailey; and aw zaid—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What the devil does it ſignify to me what he ſaid?—Hark'e, ſir, I ſee in your face you know more of your miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Dang it, then my feace do lye hugely!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Tell me the whole truth villain! or I'll ſtab you to the heart this inſtant. (Draws his ſword.)

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: (kneels) I wull, zur, indead I wull: doan't ye terrify me zo! I do forget ev'ry thing in the whole world.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Be ſincere, and depend on my rewarding you.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Why, I wiſh I meay die this maument, if conj'rer did not zeay I ſhould loſe my pleace! nay, aw do verily think aw zaid zomething o'my being put in fear o' my loife. Loard knaws, I little thought how zoon his woords would come to paſs.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Will you dally?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Zoa, as I zaid, zur, when I com'd huome again, I found all the duors aupen, and not a zoul to be zeed.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (aſide) This fellow can never mean to impoſe on me, and I muſt think this a plann'd affair'—While I was in the country, Jacob, did your miſtreſs ſee much company?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Cuompany?—noa, not to ſpeak of,—not gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Gentlewomen? blockhead! why had ſhe any male viſitors?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Anan!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I muſt brain thee at laſt, booby! Did any men come to ſee her then?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh yes, zur, yes—two gentlemen com'd almoſt ev'ry deay.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: How, two gentlemen? I ſhall run diſtracted! Young, and handſome?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Not auver young, zur, nor auver handſome; but 〈…〉 foine.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: So they came almoſt ev'ry day?—very pretty indeed, Miſs Cecilia!—was you never call'd up while they ſtaid?—did they come together or alone?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Aloane.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I thought as much; yes, I thought as much. But was you never call'd up, Jacob?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Yes, zur, when one aw um ware here one deay, I ware caal'd up for zomething or other.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Well? why don't you go on? I am on the rack!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Doan't ye look zo muortal angry then!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Well, well, I won't, my good fellow!—there's money for thy honeſty.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Well;—there aw ware—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
Speak out freely? you can tell me nothing
worſe than I imagine; you won't ſhock me in the leaſt; not at all.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Well; there aw ware pleaying on that there muſic-thing like a cuoffin, and madam ware a zinging to un like any black-bird.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: A muſic-maſter—Is that all, booby?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Yes; but t'other, zur—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Aye, I had forgot;—what of him, good Jacob? what of him?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I ware never caall'd up while aw ſteay'd; zo (I can't but zeay, I had a curoſity to knaw what brought he here,) one deay I peap'd thro' the keayhole, and zeed un— (titters) —I ſhall never forget.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Tell me what this inſtant, or I ſhall burſt with rage and ſuſpenſe.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Screaping on a leetle viddle, no bigger than my hand; while madam ware a huolding out her quoats, and dancing all round the room zoa— (mimicks the minuet aukwardly.)

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Why, I believe the impudent bumpkin dares to jeſt with my miſery! and yet I have no other avenue: for the reſt, I fear, are knaves, and he ſeems only a fool—and are theſe all that came, Jacob?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Noa, there ware one moare, zur; a leetle mon in a black quoat,—but he only com'd now and tan.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: A diſguiſe, no doubt? Yes, yes, they were artful enough.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
And zoa, ater he had done wi' my Leady, aw did ſhut his ſelf up wi' Bridget; and zoa I axed
her all about un, and zhe zaid as how aw com'd to teach madam to turn themmin great round balls all blue, and red, and yellow, that do ſtand by the books, and larned ſhe to wroite.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Yes, yes; Mrs. Bridget was in all her ſecrets, I don't doubt. If that fellow in black comes here again, keep him, if you value your life, and ſend for me. I know not what to do or think, and muſt renew my ſearch, tho' hopeleſs of ſucceſs. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Dang it! but he's in a deſprate teaking!—Rabbit me, but I ware muortally afeard aw un too, for aw flouriſh'd his zword as yeazy as I could a cudgel:—and I do think conj'urer might as well ha tuold me madam would ha' run away, while aw ware about it, and then I moight ha' run away furſt. Exit.

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.p: At length I have gained entrance into the houſe of ſhame, which now, alas! contains my darling Cecilia,—plung'd in vice, and loſt to every ſentiment, I ſpent ſo many anxious years in implanting. This does not ſeem to be the abode of pleaſure, nor have I met a ſingle being.

div.stage: Woodville entering behind, ſees Grey, and, drawing his ſword, flies at and ſeizes him.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ha! a man! and in black, as Jacob ſaid! Villain, this moment is your laſt.

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.p: (turning ſuddenly upon him) Yes, young ſeducer, add to the daughter's ruin the father's murder! Stab my heart, as you already have my happineſs.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Alas, was this her viſitor? I dare not ſpeak to him!

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.p: Emboſomed by affluence, exalted by title, peace ſtill ſhall be far from thy heart; for thou, with the worſt kind of avarice, haſt by ſpecious pretences wreſted from poverty its laſt dear poſſeſſion,—virtue.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Plerced to the ſoul, as I am by your reproaches, I dare appeal to Cecilia herſelf for a teſtimony of my contrition! How ſhall I convince you?

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.p: Hardly by a life of repentance. But I debaſe myſelf to exchange a word with you. Give me back my Cecilia!—Ruin'd as ſhe is, I yet would recover her:—give her back then to a father you firſt taught her to fear, and an habitation, too humble for any but the good to be happy in.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Alas, Sir! can you trifle with my miſery? do you give her back to the wretch who cannot ſurvive her loſs!—let me owe her hand to your bounty, tho' her heart to her own!—did you know what this elopement of her's has coſt me—

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.p: Oh, moſt accompliſh'd villain!—but think not to dupe me too.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Who but you can have robb'd me of her ſince morning?

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.p: Shallow artifice!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Hear me, Sir! and even believe me, when I ſolemnly ſwear I have deeply repented my crime, and offer'd her all the reparation in my power;—but, ſince then—

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.p: What ſince then?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Either by your means, or ſome other, ſhe has fled!

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.p: Impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Tis too true, by heav'n!

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.p: Perhaps, while you are thus ingeniouſly deluding me, ſhe indeed flies.—Study ſome other deception, while I examine the whole houſe, for nothing elſe can convince me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Woodville
sp.p: Surely this injur'd venerable man was ſent by heav'n to complete my misfortunes!—my paſſions ſubſide, but only into a vague horror and deſpondency, even more dreadful:—if with raſh hands ſhe has ſhorten'd her days, what remains of mine will be, indeed, all her father predicts! (walking by the toilette) ha, a letter!

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.p: A total lonelineſs in the houſe!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Now, ſir, be convinced!—I have juſt found a letter from her.

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.p: This cannot be the invention of a moment:—let me read it—it is, indeed, her hand. (Opens, and reads it)

body.p: Receive this as my laſt farewel.—Providence has unexpectedly ſent me a friend, whoſe protection I dare accept; and time may perhaps ſubdue a paſſion, which ſeems interwoven with my being.—forget me, I intreat; and ſeek that happineſs with another, I can never hope to beſtow or partake.—Conſoled only by reflecting, that the grief, my error occaſions, is inferior to that I ſhould have felt, had I, by an ungenerous uſe of my power, made you, in turn, my victim.—Once more, adieu!—all ſearch will certainly be fruitleſs.

postscript.p: P. S. In the cabinet you will find your valuable preſents; and the key is in a dreſſing-box.

div.stage: (Woodville ſnatches the letter, and burſts into tears)

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.p: Cecilia! I may ſay, with tears of joy, thou art, indeed, my daughter! more dear (if poſſible) than ever! a daughter monarchs might contend for, though thy weak father abjures thee!—may the friend you have found have a heart but like your own! for you, young man!—but I leave you to your anguiſh; the loſs of ſuch a woman is a ſufficient puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Stay, ſir! (riſes) by your holy profeſſion, I conjure you, ſtay!—plunge me not into total deſpair!—though without a clue to her aſylum, I would fain believe my heart will lead me to it; and let me then hope you will beſtow her on me?

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.p: There is a ſomething in your manner, young gentleman, that affects me;—I have been young, wild, and extravagant myſelf; and, what is more ſtrange, have not forgot I was ſo: my own experience proves reformation poſſible; act up to her, and atone your error.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I will endeavour it, ſir! and, oh could thoſe who yet but waver, feel what has paſſed in my heart, during the laſt hour, who would dare to deviate? Exeunt.

div.head: ACT IV.
div.stage: Bridget dreſſed in Cecilia's Clothes, mixed with every thing vulgar and tawdry.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: SO,—I am ready againſt our gentleman comes.—Deuce on him to run away laſt night, the moment I was dreſt—and with an inferial fellow too!—Lard, how can people of quality demean themſelves by keeping company with inferials!—however, one thing I am ſure of, he's too much on the fidgets to ſtay long away from our houſe; and, in the mean while, I can entertain myſelf extremely well. (Sits down to the toilette)

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: (Without) I tell ye, my leady's not at huome.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I tell you, I won't take your word for it;—ſo come, my Lord, and ſee.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Heyday, my Lord!—what's the news now, I wonder?

div.stage: Enter Lord Glenmore and the Governor; both ſtop ſhort.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Oh, I thought madam had learnt enough of the ton to lye by proxy.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Dear heart!—I am all of a twitteration!—who can theſe be?—that's my Lord, for certain!

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: The vulgarity of the wench is aſtoniſhing!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: —Um—why, a little gawky, or ſo,—there's no denying it.— (aſide) Here's a pretty diſcovery, now, after all my projects!—thank fortune, the ſecret is yet my own though.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: (Advancing to her) I ought to beg your excuſe, madam, for ſo abrupt an intruſion; but the opportunity and ſo fair a temptation will, I flatter myſelf, be a ſufficient apology.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: (aſide) He takes me for my lady, that's a ſure thing!—oh, this is charming!—you need not make no 'poligy's, my Lord;—inferials never knows how to ſuſpect people of quality; but I underſtands good breeding better.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: (aſide) Why, what a Barn-door Mawkin it is! your politeneſs, madam, can only be equalled by your beauty.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Dear heart, my Lord, you flatter me!—won't you pleaſe to ſit?— (waits affectedly 'till they conſent to ſeat themſelves)

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: (to the Governor) Surely, by uſing my title, ſhe knows me!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Zounds, I have a great mind to make her know me!—od, I ſhall never be able to contain.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: I was afraid, madam, I ſhould prove an unwelcome gueſt;—but beauty, like yours—

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p:
Does your Lordſhip think I ſo very handſome,
then?—Lord, how lucky was my dreſſing myſelf!

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: (Aſide) Affected ideot!—I was afraid, Madam, too of meeting Woodville here— (aſide) I know not what to ſay to her.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: He has not been here this morning; but, if he had, he knows better than to ax ater my company, I do aſſure you, my—Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: I have been told he intends marrying you; what a pity to monopolize ſuch merit!

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: If he has any ſuch kind intention, 'tis more than I knows of, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: His keeping that wiſe reſolution from you, is ſome little comfort, however.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: But, I promiſe ye, I ſhall make a rare perſon of quality—for I loves cards, coaches, dancing, and dreſs, to my very heart;—nothing in the world better—but Blindman's Buff. I had ſome thoughts of taking a trip to Sadler's Wells or Fox Hall, but they don't begin till five o'clock.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: (Aſide) Ha, ha! tho' ſhe can hardly ſpell out the Ten Commandments, ſhe cou'd break every one with as much eaſe and impudence, as if ſhe had been bred in the circle of St. James's.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: But, Madam, you know, allowing Woodville willing to marry you, it is not in his power while his father lives, without forfeiting his fortune, the value of which you doubtleſs underſtand?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Oh, yes, yes, for ſartain, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Who knows too, how far an incenſed parent may carry his reſentment!—he might find means to entrap and puniſh you.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—he entrap me!—that would be a good jeſt!—no, no, I have more of the lady of quality than to be ſo eaſily caught.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: (mimicking her) He, he, he! that is the only particular in which you have nothing at all of the lady of quality.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: With me you may ſhare a higher rank and larger fortune without thoſe fears—I am of an age.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Yes, one may ſee that without being a conjuror—why, will you marry me, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Convince me that you don't love this Woodville, and I know not how far my paſſion may carry me.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Love him? do you think I know no more of high life than that comes to?—To be ſure, he is a ſweet pretty man, and all that;—but, as to love,—I loves nobody half ſo well as myſelf.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, I believe you; and wiſh he had the whole benefit of the declaration: [to the Governor] her ingratitude is as ſhocking as her ignorance, and Bridewell too gentle a puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Then build a bridewell large enough to contain the whole ſex; for the only diff'rence between her and the reſt is,—this Country Mawkin tells what the Town-bred Miſſes conceal.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Why, Governor! you are as teſty as if you had had the care of her education.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I the care?—zounds, what I ſay is merely from friendſhip to your Lordſhip.—I hate to ſee you deceive yourſelf.— (Aſide) Surely he can never ſuſpect! (Bridget is employ'd in cramming trinkets from the dreſſing-table into her pockets.)

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Now I am ready to go, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Reflect, Madam!—it would hurt me to have you ſay I deceiv'd you—if you ſhould repent—I am much afraid you will—

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: What, wh • n I am a Lady?—oh, I'll venture that, and attend you.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: (roughly ſnatching her other hand) To where you little dream of, you vain, affected, preſuming, ignorant baggage!

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Hey-day!—my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Appeal not to me, baſe woman!—know, I am the father of that poor dupe, Woodville.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Dear heart! be ye indeed?—what will become of me then?

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: And, as a moderate puniſhment for your hypocriſy, ambition, and ingratitude, ſentence you to be ſhut up for life in a monaſtery.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Oh Lord! among monſters?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: No, Ignoramus! no;—among Nuns:—tho' they are but monſters in human nature either.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: What, where they'll cut off my hair, and make me wear ſackcloth next to my ſkin?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Yes, if they leave you any ſkin at all.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Oh dear, dear, dear! (ſobs and groans) upon my bended knees, I do beg you won't ſend me there!—why I ſhall go mallancholly—I ſhall make away with myſelf for certain; and my ghoſt will appear to you all in white!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: All in black, I rather think; for the devil a ſpeck of white is there in your whole compoſition.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Your conduct, wretch! juſtifies a ſeverer ſentence—to ſeduce him from his duty, was crime enough.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Who, I ſeduce him? I did not, my Lord—indeed I did not.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Have you not own'd—

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: No, indeed, no; that I wiſh'd to take my Lady's place, I believe I did own:—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! very prettily devis'd, faith, for a young beginner!—come, come, (chucking her under the chin) we muſt give you credit for this, Miſs—your Lady? ha, ha,—ha!

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p:
Shallow ſubterfuge!
Enter Vane and the Slaves.
Vane, is all ready?—ſeize this woman, and obſerve my orders!

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Ah dear heart! I ſhall die away if the blacks do but touch me—indeed you do miſtake!—I be no Lady—I be only Bridget.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I would give ten thouſand pounds that you were only Bridget, you artful puſs!—Zounds, tho' I could one moment ſtrangle the pug's face in her own necklace, yet the next I can hardly prevail on myſelf to puniſh her—what the devil had I now to do in England? or what the devil had I ever to do in Wales?—Phew! I could dethrone fifty Nabobs without half the fatigue and anxiety of this moment.—Take her away, however! and let us try how Miſs likes riding out in her own coach.

div.stage: Vane and the Slaves ſeize her; ſhe ſcreams out, and catches Lord Glenmore's coat, falling on her knees.—Jacob enters, her back to him.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Why, what a dickens be ye all at here?—Zoa, what's my Leady there?

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: See there now,—Oh the artful Jezebel!

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Oh, Jacob! Why don't ye ſee I am Bridget?—Pray ſatisfy my Lord here.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Why, be ye Bridget?—Never truſt me elſe!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Here a fool of t'other ſex now, can hardly take a hint though ſo plainly given him!—Thanks to the natural difference, for art is nature in woman.— (L. Glen. draws him aſide.)

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Auh Bridget, Bridget! Where didſt thee get thee ſum foine claws?—Noa, noa, as thee'ſt brew'd thee meayſt beake.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Oh, do ye take pity on me!—Why they be going to carry me to ſome outlandiſh place, and make a nun of me!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: A nun? what's that? any thing Chriſtin? well, if I do ſpake to um, will ye hae me?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Oh, yes, yes, yes!

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Brother! I ſhall leave you to the completion of this affair; I am ſick to the ſoul of the gawky—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I don't doubt it,—I don't doubt it.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: (To Vane.) Convey her to my houſe, and lock her up in one of the lofts over the ſtables;—go the backway, and even the family need know nothing of the matter. The Chaplain will provide a licence, and be ready—Courage, my lad, and depend upon my gratitude! Exit.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Will you take her, or no?—I ſhall never be able to ſtifle my agitation; and burſt with rage if I ſhew it.—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Why, zure, zure, ye won't carr' away our Bridget?

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Oh, ſhe has beat her meaning into thy thick ſcull a laſt?—Pr'ythee, keep thy block-head out of my way, if thou mean'ſt to keep it on thy own ſhoulders.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Why, be ye in arneſt then? dear heart alive! why this is couſin Bridget!

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Only ſend for Mr. Woodville?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Prettily devis'd again! ha, ha, ha! doſt think, my little dear! we have lived three times as long as your Ladyſhip to learn a quarter as much?—Send for Mr. Woodville, hey?—No, no; you won't find us quite ſo ſimple.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Oh doan't ye, doan't ye, carr' off zhe, or if ye wull, do pray take I.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: Yes, you would be a choice piece of lumber truly.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Drag her away this moment.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Oh dear, oh dear! to be hanged at laſt for another's crime is all that vexes me.

div.stage: They carry her off, Governor follows.
Cecilia enters, and ſits down to embroidery.
div.p: How fond, how weak, how ungrateful, are out hearts!—mine ſtill will preſumptuouſly fancy this houſe its home, and ally itſelf to ev'ry one to whom Woodville is dear.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Oh heaven's, my Lord!—how unlucky!—if I go, he may find the Captain with Miſs Mortimer.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: You ſee, madam, you have only to retire to engage us to purſue you, even to rudeneſs.—But, tell me, can it be your own choice to puniſh us ſo far as to prefer ſolitude to our ſociety?

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: I know myſelf too well, my Lord, to receive diſtinctions of which I am unworthy;—yet think not, therefore, I fail in reſpect.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: But, is that charming boſom ſuſceptible of nothing beyond reſpect? why is it capable of inſpiring a paſſion it cannot participate?

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Your goodneſs, my Lord—my profound veneration, will always attend you—but, the more generouſly you are inclined to forget what is due to yourſelf, the more ſtrongly it is impreſſed on my memory.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Were what you ſay true, the bounties of nature atone amply to you for the parſimony of fortune; nor would your want of every other advantage leſſen your merit, or my ſenſe of it.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: (aſide) Had he thought thus a few months ſince, how happy had I now been!—Your approbation at once flatters and ſerves me, by juſtifying Miſs Mortimer's protection of me.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Her partiality for you, does her more honour, than it can ever do you advantage. But, you muſt tell me, how ſhe gain'd firſt the happineſs of knowing you?

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: My—my Lord, by a misfortune ſo touching—

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Nay, I would not diſtreſs you neither; yet, I own, madam, I wiſh to make a propoſal worth a ſerious anſwer; but ought firſt to know, why you affect a myſtery? Tell me then, my dear, ev'ry incident of your life, and I will raiſe you to a title, I may without vanity ſay, many have aſpired to!

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: You oppreſs my very ſoul, my Lord! But, alas! unconquerable obſtacles deprive me for ever of that title. Neither would I obtain it by alienating ſuch a ſon from ſuch a father.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Put him entirely out of the queſtion; the meanneſs of his conduct acquits me to myſelf. Do you know, madam, he has reſolved to marry a creature of low birth, illiterate, vulgar, and impudent? and, to complete her perfections, ſhe has been his miſtreſs at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Surely he knows, and purpoſely ſhocks me thus. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: But your integrity doesn't render you leſs amiable in my eyes; it greatly enhances ev'ry other merit. As to his wretch, I have her in my power, and ſhall make her dearly repent.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Then I am loſt indeed! (aſide) You have, my Lord; tho' I know not how, diſcovered.— (Riſes in confuſion.)

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: (riſes, taking ſnuff, without looking at her) Oh, nothing more eaſy, madam; I had him carefully traced to her houſe; and, during his abſence, took ſervants and forced her away.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: (aſide) That, however, cannot be me; every word ſeems to add to a myſtery I dare not enquire into.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: But why waſte one precious moment on ſuch an animal? what are theſe unconquerable obſtacles?

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Spare me, my Lord; your indulgence induces me to try again to ſoften your reſolutions reſpecting your ſon: deprived of the weak, the guilty, the miſerable wretch you juſtly condemn, a little time will (no doubt) incline him to his duty. I ſhould have your pardon to ſolicit, my Lord, but that your own openneſs authorizes mine.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: But, can you, who ſo powerfully plead the cauſe of another, be deaf to the ſighs of a man who adores you? who offers you a rank—

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Be ſatisfied, my Lord, with knowing I have all that eſteem your merit claims; which influences me beyond every caſual advantage.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: But, madam—

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Alas, my Lord!— (burſts into tears aſide) —Be ſilent, if poſſible, both pride and virtue. I have deſerved, and will ſubmit to it—yet ſurely the bitterneſs of this moment expiates all paſt offences. Exit.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Amiable creature! what an amazing elegance of mind and perſon! Tears were her only anſwers to my queſtions, and bluſhes to my looks: yet theſe only heighten a curioſity they have ſoftened into love. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: No intelligence of my Cecilia yet!—were I only aſſured of her ſafety, it would be ſome conſolation.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Zur, Zur!—I do meake ſo bowld as to ax to ſpake to you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Jacob! my honeſt fellow, the very ſight of thee revives my hopes, and ſets my heart in motion!—well, what's the news?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Zurprizing news indeed, zur!—Loord, I thought I ſhould never meat wi'ye;—I com'd to your lodgings twice, and ye warn't up.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Up! 'sdeath, you ignorant Booby! why didn't you order them to rouſe me that moment?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Loord, zur! why, your gentleman (as they do caal un) were ſo terrable foine, I ware afeard of affronting un!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Plague on the ſtupidity of both, ſay I!—But what's all this to the purpoſe? the news? the news?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Las-adeazy! mourtal bad news, indeed!—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You tedious blockhead! is your lady return'd?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Noa, Zur. (Shaking his head very mournfully.)

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (aſide) The horrid forebodings of my heart recur; yet, ſurely ſhe could not be ſo deſperate!—ſhocking as the ſuſpenſe is, I more dread the certainty.—Speak, however, my good fellow! (Jacob wipes his eyes) —I ſhall ever value your ſenſibility.—Tell me, then, the ſimple truth, whatever it may be?—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I wull, Zur, I wull.—There has com'd two foine gentleman, wi zwords by their zides, juſt for all the world like yourn.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Well, and what did theſe gentleman ſay?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Why, they went up ſtears, willy nilly, and carr'd off—our Bridget. (Burſts out a crying.)

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You impudent, ignorant clown! I'll give you cauſe for your tears. (Shakes him.)

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Loord! Loord!—do ye ha a little Chriſtin commiſeration—well, if I ever do coume nigh ye again, I do wiſh ye may break every buone in my zkin.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (Walking about in a rage) To inſult me with your own paltry love affairs! theſe great and mighty gentlemen were only conſtables I dare ſwear, and your fears converted their ſtaves to ſwords.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ay, but that a'nt the worſt nither. I do verily think my turn wull cuome next;—cant zleep n my bed for thinking on't, nor enjoy a meal's meat:—zo, except you do bring your zword, and coume and live in our houze, I wull guo out on't, that's a zure thing; for I had rather ſceare craws at a graat a deay all my loife long, than bide there to be ſo terrified.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Sceare craws truly? why, the craws, will ſceare you, ye hen-hearted puppy!—there, teake that, (gives him money) and guo huome, or to the devil, ſo you never fall in my way again.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Zome faulk that I do knaw wull zee the black gentleman firſt, 'tis my belief—zoa I had beſt keep out o his woiy too.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Woodville, what's the matter? why you will raiſe the neighbourhood.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Here's a peaper houſemaid do zend you, wi her humble duty; but, if zo be it do put ye in another deſperate teaking, I do huope ye wull zend for zhe to beat, and not I.—Loord! Loord! what wull becuome of me in this woide world of London! (Exit Jacob.)

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! he is a choice fellow!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: A heart, oppreſſed with its own feelings, fears ev'ry thing. I have hardly courage to open a letter without an addreſs.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Come, come, give it me then?—hey, what? confuſion!—was ever any thing ſo unlucky? (attempts to tear it.)

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (ſnatches it from him) Ha! it is important then?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Why will you invent torments for yourſelf? (Aſide) —My own letter by ev'ry thing careleſs—here's a ſtroke—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (reads in a broken voice and manner) Woodville on the brink of marriage—you will be diſengaged—a nobleman—(damnation!)—heart and fortune at her feet —(I'll let his ſoul out there) hell and furies!—but I will find him, if money—never will I cloſe my eyes till—Oh Cecilia— (throws himſelf into a ſeat.)

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: This is the moſt unforeſeen—I know not what to ſay to him—prythee, Woodville! do not ſacrifice ſo many reaſonable preſumptions in her favour, to a paper that may be a forgery, for aught you know!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Oh Charles! that I could think ſo!—but I have ſeen the villain's execrable hand ſomewhere! Did you never ſee the hand?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Um—I can't but own I have,—what the devil ſhall I ſay to him— Aſide.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Woodville, my dear boy! I am come to have a little talk with thee.—Charles! don't run away!—you are in all your couſin's ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What ſhould poſſeſs this tireſome mortal to come here?—I ſhould have waited on you, in half an hour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Ay, and that's what I wanted to avoid:—The more I talk to your father, Frank, the more I find him fixed on the match with his Miſs Mortimer! Nay, he tells me, he will have you married this very day.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That's mighty probable, in the humour I am in.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Ah, Frank! the girl I offer thee—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Is no more agreeable to me than her you deſpiſe.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: How do you know that, peppercorn?—how do you know that?—od, I could tell you—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And, to tell you my full mind. Sir, I had rather make myſelf a wretch to gratify my father, than any other man.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Od! thou art ſo obſtinate, boy, there's no diſliking thee.— (Aſide) I don't ſee why I am obliged
to know his Miſs is my daughter—I have a great mind to own what we have done with her; and, if he will marry, e'en take care nobody hinders him! then, trump up a farce about forgiving them;—and yet, it goes againſt my conſcience to puniſh the puppy for life, though he has puniſhed me pretty ſufficiently, by the Lord Harry.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I don't like this affair at all, and tremble for my Sophia, when I ſee this odd ſoul ſo inveterate againſt her.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: (to Woodville) Well, my lad! do you know I am as deep in all your ſecrets as your favourite valet de chambre?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I don't underſtand you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Pho, pho, pho! keep that face till I ſhew thee one as ſolemn as my Lord's. Why ſhould not you pleaſe yourſelf, and marry your Miſs, inſtead of your father's?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhing!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Od, if you turn out the honeſt fellow I take you for, I know a pretty round ſum, an onion and a black coat may one day or other entitle you to; ſo never mind Lord Gravity's reſentment.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I act from better motives, Sir, and were unworthy your wealth could it tempt me to diſobey the beſt of fathers.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
(paſſionately) Why then, marry Miſs Mortimer, and oblige him: take a back ſeat in your own coach, get a family of pale-faced brats, born with oſtrich-feathers on their heads; and hate away a long life with all due decorum!—Zounds, here's a fellow
more whimſical than—even myſelf.—Yeſterday you would have the puſs ſpite of ev'ry body; but, you no ſooner find it in your power to oblige your beſtfriend, by humouring your inclinations, than, lo! you are taken with a moſt violent ſit of duty and ſubmiſſion!—Od, you don't know what you have loſt by it!—but, ſince you are bent on croſſing me, I'll croſs you, and once for all too.—My ſecret ſhall henceforth be as impenetrable as the philoſopher's ſtone.—Ay, ſtare as you pleaſe, I'll give you more years than you have yet ſeen days to gueſs it in. Exit.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What this uncle of ours can mean is quite beyond my gueſs!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What ſignifies ſeeking to expound by reaſon, actions in which it had no ſhare?—his brain is indubitably touched!—but Cecilia lies heavy on my heart, and excludes ev'ry other thought.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Time may explain the ſecret of that letter, which, I will lay my life, ſhe deſpiſes:—a woman who did not, would have kept it from your hands.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That's true, indeed!—if I wrong her, and this was but an inſult,—there is a noble ſincerity in her own letter which ſets ſuſpicion at defiance.—If he ſtumbled on one word of truth during this viſit, the criſis of my fate approaches.—Oh, wherever thou art, if the exalted being I will ſtill hope my Cecilia, thou ſhalt I know I have at leaſt deſerv'd thee! Exeunt.

div.head: ACT V.
div.stage: SCENE, A mean Room; Boots, Bridles, &c. hanging all round.
Bridget fitting very mournfully, her fine Clothes in great Diſorder;—a Table by her, with a ſmall Roll, a Glaſs of Water, an old dog's-ear'd Book, and a Bit of Looking-glaſs.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: DEAR heart! dear heart! what a miſerable time have I paſs'd! and, where I be to paſs my whole life, my Lord here only knows!—I have not much ſtomach indeed;—neither have I much breakfaſt. (Eats a bit of Bread and burſts into tears.)

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Had I more ſins to anſwer for than a college of Jeſuits, I ſurely expiate them all, by going through a purgatory in this life beyond what they have invented for the other.—This vulgar Maux of mine haunts my imagination, in ev'ry ſhape but that I hoped to ſee her in;—I dare hardly truſt myſelf to ſpeak to her!—od, I would not have the extirpation of the whole female ſex depend upon my caſting-vote while I am in this humor.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Mercy on me! here's that croſs old gentleman again! what will become of me?—do, pray, ſtrange ſir! be ſo generous as to tell me what is next to be done with me?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why, juſt whatever I pleaſe, you audacious baggage!— (Aſide) od, now I think on't, I have a great mind to try a few ſoft words, and dive into all the ſecrets of the little ignoramus.—Come, ſuppoſe I had a mind to grant you your freedom, how would you requite me?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Dear heart! why, I'd love you for ever and ever.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: 'dzounds, that's a favor I could very readily diſpenſe with;—and yet 'tis natural to the poor wench:—ah! if thou had'ſt been a good girl, thou hadſt been a happy one.—Hark'ye, miſs! confeſs all your ſins, that's the only way to eſcape, I promiſe you! and, if you conceal the leaſt, I'll—od, I don't know what I'll do to you.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: I will; I will, ſir, indeed, as I hope to be married.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Married, you ſlut! bad as that is, it's too good for you:—come, tell me all your adventures?—deſcribe the behaviour of the young villain who ſeduced you;—where did you ſee him firſt?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Ugh, ugh,—At church, ſir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: At church, quotha?—a pretty place to commence an intrigue in!—and how long was it before you came to this admirable agreement?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Umh?—why—Sunday was Midſummer-eve,—and Sunday ater was madam's wedding-day,—and Monday was our fair, and—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Oh, curſe your long hiſtories!—and, what then ſaid Woodville?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Oh Lord, nothing at all—why, it warn't he.—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: No.— (ready to burſt with paſſion) Who, who, who? tell me that, and quite diſtract me!

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Timothy Hobbs, Squire's gardiner.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: An abſolute clown— (walks about half groaning with rage and diſappointment) who, oh! who would be a father?—I could laugh,—cry,—die,—with ſhame and anger!—ſince the man, who corrupted, left her only one virtue, would he had depriv'd her of that too!—oh, that ſhe had but ſkill enough to lye well!

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Whether I can or no, I'll never ſpeak truth again, that's a ſure thing!—what do I get by it, or any poor ſouls of the female kind?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I am incapable of thinking;—ev'ry plan, ev'ry reſource thus overturn'd;—I muſt be wiſer than all the world?—This fool's head of mine muſt take to teaching truly! as if I could eradicate the ſtamp of nature, or regulate the ſenſes, by any thing but reaſon—don't pipe, baggage! to me;—you all can do that, when too late:—when I have conſidered whether I ſhall hang myſelf or not, I'll let you know whether I ſhall tuck you up along with me, you little wretch, you! Exit.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Well, ſure I have at laſt gueſs'd where I am ſhut up!—it muſt be Bedlam; for the old gentleman is out of his mind, that's a ſure thing!

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! my future father-in-law ſeems to have got a quietus of my intended; and, faith, ſo wou'd any man who was not in love with a certain forty thouſand;—to be ſure, in plain Engliſh, ſhe is a glorious mawkin!— (to her) —well, madam, how are you pleas'd with your preſent mode of living?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Living, do you call it?—I think, 'tis only ſtarving.—Why, I ſhall eat my way thro' the walls very ſhortly.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Faith, Miſs, they uſe you but ſo ſo, that's the truth on't; and I muſt repeat, even to your face, what I ſaid to my Lord, that your youth, beauty, and accompliſhments, deſerve a better fate.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Dear heart! Bedlam, did I ſay, I was in! why, I never knew a more ſenſibler, genteeler, prettier ſort of a man in my life. (aſide) —I am ſure, Sir, if I was to ſtudy ſeven years, I ſhou'd never know what I have done to diſcommode them, not I.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Oh Lard, my dear! only what is done ev'ry day by half your ſex without puniſhment—however, you are to ſuffer for all, it ſeems?—you ſee your fare for life!—a dungeon, coarſe rags, and the ſame handſome allowance of bread and water twice a day.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Oh, dear me!—why, I ſhall be an otomy in a week!

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: And an old black to guard you, more ſulky and hideous, than thoſe in the Arabian Night's Entertainments.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Why, ſure they will let you come and ſee me, Sir? I ſhall certainly ſwound away, ev'ry time I look at the naſty old black.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: This is the laſt time your dungeon (which your preſence renders a palace to me) will ever be open to one viſitor—unleſs—unleſs—I cou'd contrive—but no, it would be my ruin:—yet who woud'nt venture ſomething for ſuch a charming creature? you could endear even ruin.—Tell me, then, what reward you would beſtow on a man who ventur'd all to give you freedom?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Nay, I don't know; you're ſuch a dear ſweet kind ſoul, I ſhan't ſtand with you for a trifle.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Ahey! Miſs will be as much too complying in a minute.—Well, then, my dear! I muſt marry you, or you will ſtill be in the power of your enemies.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Hey?—what? do I hear rightly? marry me?— (aſide) —why, this will be the luckieſt day's work I ever did!—nay, Sir, if you ſhould be ſo generous, I hope I ſhall live to make you amends!

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: (aſide) The only amends you can make me, is by dying—and now, my dear! I will own to you, I have the licenſe in my pocket; and my Lord, as eager as myſelf.—Our chaplain will do us the favour with more expedition than he ſays grace before meat!—Well done, Vane! egad, thy lucky ſtar predominates!— (Aſide—takes her arm.)

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Surely my locking up does end very comical. Exeunt arm in arm.

sp.speaker: M. Mor.
sp.p: Woodville is now with his father, and both in the deciſive mood.—Oh, Charles! as the moment approaches nearer, your influence becomes inſenſibly leſs powerful:—the frantic fits of the Governor; the ſolemn abſurdity of my Lord—but, above all, the behaviour of Woodville, hurts and alarms me!—ſtill cautious not to offend his father, he has tried ev'ry way to extort the refuſal from me; but, by a pardonable equivocation, I left him hopeleſs, and aſſured him I ſhould, to the utmoſt of my power, obey my benefactor.—Why, why did you marry one, who could give you nothing but her heart?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I ſhall not anſwer, till you can name me an equivalent—truſt to my management, my dear Sophia.—I ſtill flatter myſelf, one ſtorm will ſettle the tenor of our lives—if not; while acquitted to Heav'n, the world, and ourſelves, we may ſtruggle with ſpirit againſt fortune; and ſometimes owe our deareſt enjoyments to her fluctuations.

sp.speaker: M. Mor.
sp.p: By ſentiments like theſe you won my very ſoul; and to retain for ever a heart ſo invaluable, I have ventur'd the diſpleaſure of my benefactor: but our hearts will not always follow the lead of our reaſon, nor, when I conſider the cauſe, can I repent the deviation of mine.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Think, if you pity yourſelf, what you can give to Cecilia; and fortify her mind againſt too ſtrong a ſenſe of her frailty. For my part, I muſt watch whatever is going on.

sp.speaker: M. Mor.
sp.p: So, you leave me out of the plot?—well, if it ends happily, I ſhall be contented; and, like the world, meaſuring your merit by your ſucceſs, will declare you a moſt inimitable ſchemer.—Adieu!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Nay, ſtay a moment!

sp.speaker: M. Mor.
sp.p: Not for the world; for here comes your uncle, with a face more petrifying than Meduſa's. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I have lived fifty eight years, five months, and certain odd days, to find out I am a fool at laſt; but I will live as many more, before I add the diſcovery that I am a knave too.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What the devil can he be now hatching?—miſchief, I fear?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Dear fortune! let me eſcape this once undiſcover'd, and I compound for all the reſt.—Charles! the news of the houſe? for the politicks of this family are employment for ev'ry individual in it.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Bella, horrida bella, Sir!—my Lord is determined to bring his ſon's duty to an immediate teſt,— (aſide) thanks to his friend's ſchemes and his miſtreſs's beauty.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
What poor malicious wretches are we by nature?—Zounds, if I could not find in my heart to
rejoice at thinking every one here will be as mortified and diſappointed as a certain perſon that ſhall be nameleſs.—So, ſo; here they come, faith, to argue the point in open court.

div.stage: Enter Lord Glenmore followed by Woodville.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Without this proof of your obedience, all you can urge, Sir, is ineffectual.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: While obedience was poſſible, I never ſwerv'd, my Lord; but, when you command me to make myſelf wretched, a ſuperior duty cancels that:—already bound by a voluntary, an everlaſting vow, I cannot break it without offending heav'n, nor keep it without offending you.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: (aſide) What's this? chop'd about again!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Did you once know the incomparable merits of my love, even your Lordſhip's prejudices muſt give way to your reaſon.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Mere dotage.—But, had ſhe more than any one woman ever yet poſſeſs'd, doesn't her conduct equally evince her folly and depravity?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Cover'd, as I ought to be, with confuſion and remorſe; I will own ſhe was ſeduc'd and deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: (aſide) Ah, poor boy!—one of the two was woefully deceiv'd ſure enough.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Oh, your conſcience may be very eaſy on that account; it could not require much art to deceive ſuch an ideot.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: No, no, my Lord; why paint the devil blacker than he is? not an ideot neither.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Sir, my father's freedom of ſpeech I muſt endure;—but yours—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: You muſt endure too, young Sir, or I ſhall bite my tongue off.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: But, my Lord! that dear unhappy girl is no longer a ſubject of debate,—ſhe evidently proves her merit by her flight.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Would you make a virtue from not doing ill, when it is no longer in your power?—Woodville! I was once weak enough to believe indulgence the ſureſt way of obtaining your duty and eſteem.—My eyes are at laſt opened,—Miſs Mortimer is worthy a better huſband; but you are her's, or no ſon of mine.—I ſolemnly promiſed this to her dying father, and will acquit myſelf at all events.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Can you reſolve to ſacrifice me to a promiſe made before we could judge of each other?—You never felt, Sir, the compulſion you practice;—will you diſſolve the firſt band of morality, and ſee your highly-eſtimated title end in me? for never will I on theſe terms continue it.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: I almoſt wiſh I never had continued it.— (Walks in anger.). I am determined, Woodville! and nothing but Miſs Mortimer's refuſal can break the match.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I ſhall not put that in her power, my Lord? Permit me to tell you, no ſon was ever more ſenſible of a father's kindneſs: but, if I can purchaſe its continuance only with my honour and my happineſs, it would be too dearly bought.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: 'Tis well, ſir.—I have liſtened to you ſufficiently. Now hear ME. Know, this worthleſs wretch, you prefer to your duty, is in my power; nay, in this houſe.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: (aſide) The devil ſhe is! how in the name of ill-luck ſhould he find that out?—my fine ſcheme entirely blown up, by Jupiter!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Why play thus upon me, my Lord?—her letter—

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: What, has ſhe wrote to you?—that I was not aware of, nor indeed ſuſpected ſhe could write.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: No, not ſo ignorant as that neither. I order'd ſhe ſhould write too!

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: You order'd ſhe ſhould write?—let me tell you, ſir, it was wronging my confidence!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: No, I did not order ſhe ſhould write;—I mean,—I mean,—zounds! I don't know what I mean!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: So it ſeems, indeed; ſince hardly half an hour ago my uncle himſelf perſuaded me to marry my love.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Here's a curſed affair now!

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Can this be poſſible? Let me tell you, Governor, if, preſuming upon your wealth, you play a double part in my family—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Zounds! nobody knows his own part in your family, that I ſee! and this fellow, too, to teize me, whom I lov'd above all in it Why, I ſpoke entirely from regard to him. If, ſince then I have diſcovered
a bumpkin was beforehand with him in the poſſeſſion of his miſs—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: If any one, beſide yourſelf, ſir, durſt tell ſuch a falſhood, it would coſt a life.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Yes; and, if any one beſide myſelf durſt tell me ſuch a truth, it would coſt a ſoul perhaps.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: This is more unintelligible than all the reſt.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: To end theſe altercations;—upon yourſelf, Woodville, ſhall depend the fortune of this wretch, to whom you have been ſo groſs a dupe as to juſtify the imputation of folly. Why, even without knowing me, ſhe ridiculed your paſſion, and offered to leave you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Impoſſible!

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Dare you diſbelieve me, ſir?—nay, ſhe ſhall be produced, and obliged to confeſs her arts;—then bluſh and obey! Here, Vane! Governor, the keys! Exit.

div.stage: Woodville walks behind, in great agitation.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Now could I find in my heart to make this ſtory into a ballad, as a warning to all meddling puppies; and then hang myſelf, that it may conclude with a grace. Zounds, he muſt be endued with ſupernatural intelligence. Juſt when I was ſaying a thouſand civil things to myſelf on my ſucceſs, to have my mine ſprung before my eyes by the enemy; and, inſtead of ſerving my friend and myſelf, become a meer tool to old Gravity's revenge! 'Pſhaw! however, we muſt make the beſt of a bad matter.—Woodville, what do'ſt mean to do, man?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Let them produce my Cecilia!—then ſeize, and protect her to the laſt moment of my life.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And I will aſſiſt you to the laſt moment of mine.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: My generous couſin! this is indeed friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Not ſo very generous, if you knew all.

div.stage: Re-enter Lord Glenmore and the Governor, with Bridget holding a handkerchief to her eyes, Vane following; Woodville flies and claſps her in his arms; Harcourt takes her hand.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: My love! my life!—do I once again behold thee?—fear nothing!—you here are ſafe from all the world!—will you not bleſs me with one look?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p:
(looking at him and Harcourt with ridiculous diſtreſs)
oh, dear me!

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: I have put it out of your power to marry, Sir, otherwiſe you may take her.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Take her!—what poor farce is this?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Hey-day! more incomprehenſibilities.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Aſide Now for the eclairciſſement—ſince, if the Governor doesn't acknowledge her in his firſt rage and confuſion, I may never be able to make him!—I humbly hope, Mr. Woodville will pardon me, if, with her own conſent and my Lord's, I this morning married this young lady.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Zounds, you dog, what's that?—you married her?—why, how did you dare—and you
too, my Lord!—what the devil, did you conſent to this?

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: Believe me, ſir, I didn't then know ſhe was your daughter.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Daughter!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: So, it's out, after all:—it's a lye, you dog! you did know ſhe was my daughter;—you all knew it;—you all conſpired to torment me!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! confound your mirth!—as if I had not plagues enough already.—And you have great reaſon to grin too, my Lord, when you have thrown away my Gawky on your impudent valet.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Who could ever have dreamt of—ha, ha, ha—of finding this your little wonder of the country, brother?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Nay, my Lord, ſhe's the little wonder of the town, too.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Mighty well,—mighty well,—mighty well; pray, take your whole laugh out, good folks! ſince this is, poſitively, the laſt time of my entertaining you in this manner.—A cottage ſhall henceforth be her portion, and a rope mine.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: If you are my papa, I think you might give ſome better proof of your kindneſs;—but I ſhan't ſtir;—why, I married on purpoſe that I might not care for you.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Why, thou eternal torment!—my original ſin!—whoſe firſt fault was the greateſt frailty of woman; and whoſe ſecond, her greateſt folly! do'ſt
thou, or the deſigning knave who has entrapped thee merely for that purpoſe, imagine my wealth ſhall ever reward incontinence and ingratitude?—no; go knit ſtockings to ſome regiment where he is preferred to be drummer!—warm yourſelf when the ſun ſhines!—ſoak ev'ry hard-earn'd cruſt in your own tears, and repent at leiſure. Exit in a rage.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: He to ridicule my mode of education!—but, what is the meaning of all this?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Truly, my Lord, I believe it would be very hard to find any for either my uncle's words or actions!—I am equally at a loſs to gueſs as to Bridget here.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: Hey, what? Bridget, did you ſay, ſir? why, you little ugly witch! are you really Bridget?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Why, I told ye ſo, all along; but you woud'nt believe me?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Oh dear heart!—I am now as much afeard of my new huſband as father.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: For thee, Wench—

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: (Pops upon her knees) Oh, no more locking up, for goodneſs ſake, my Lord!—I be ſick enough of paſſing for a lady: but, if old Scratch ever puts ſuch a trick again in my head, I hope—your Lordſhip will catch me! that's all. Exit.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: I ſhall run diſtracted! have I married an—and all for nothing too?

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p:
A puniſhment peculiarly juſt, as it reſults from abuſing my confidence.—Hence, Wretch!
nor ever, while you live, appear again in my preſence.
Exit Vane, looking furiouſly after Bridget.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: 'Tis time to return to ourſelves. We ſhall ſoon come to an eclairciſſement, Woodville!—Since you won't marry, I will.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: And you ſhall judge of my choice. Exit.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Now for it;—whatever devil diverts himſelf among us to-day, I ſee he owes my ſagacious Lord here a grudge, as well as the reſt; and I foreſee that his wife and the Governor's daughter will prove equally entertaining.

div.stage: Enter Lord Glenmore leading Cecilia, followed by Miſs Mortimer.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: This lady, Sir, I have ſelected;—a worthy choice.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I dream, ſurely!—that lady your choice?—yours.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Ungrateful ſon! had ſuch been yours—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Why, this very Angel is mine, my Cecilia, my firſt, my only love!

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: How!—

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord!—you now know the unhappy object at once of your reſentment, contempt, and admiration!—my own misfortunes I had learnt to bear, but thoſe of Woodville overpower me!—I deliver myſelf up to your juſtice; content to be ev'ry way his victim, ſo I am not his ruin.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: But to find you in this houſe—

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Your generous nephew and the amiable Miſs Mortimer diſtinguiſh'd me with the only aſylum could ſhelter me from your ſon!

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: They diſtinguiſhed themſelves!—Oh, Woodville! did I think an hour ago I could be more angry with you?—How durſt you warp a mind ſo noble?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: It is a crime my life cannot expiate,—yet, if the ſincereſt anguiſh—

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: I have one act of juſtice ſtill in my power;—my prejudice in favour of birth, and even a ſtronger prejudice, is corrected by this lovely girl:—of her goodneſs of heart, and greatneſs of mind, I have had inconteſtible proofs, and, if I thought you, Frank—

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Yet, ſtay, my Lord! nor kill me with too much kindneſs.—Once your generoſity might have made me happy, now only miſerable.—My reaſon, my pride, nay even my love, induces me to refuſe, as the only way to prove I deſerve him!—he has taught me to know the world too late, nor will I retort on him the contempt I have incurr'd:—Mr. Woodville will tell you whether I have not ſolemnly vow'd—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Not to accept me without the conſent of both fathers; and, if mine conſents, what doubt—
Stop that old man! ſtop that mad parſon! ſtop him!
Nothing ſhall ſtop me in purſuit of my— (enters) Ha! ſhe is—ſhe is here indeed! providence has at length directed me to her (runs to Cecilia.)

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: My father! cover'd with ſhame let me ſink before you.

sp.speaker: L. Glen. and Har.
sp.p: Her father!

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.p: Riſe, my glorious girl! riſe purified and forgiven! riſe to pity with me the weak minds that know not all thy value, and venerate the noble ones that do.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Hey! is it poſſible! Grey, is this my—

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; this is your Cecilia, my Cecilia, the object of your avowed rejection and contempt!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Rejection and contempt! ſtand out of the way—let me embrace my daughter—let me take her once more to my heart— (runs and embraces her.)

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: His daughter!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Yes, my friends, this is really my daughter—my own Cecilia, as ſure as I am an old fool after being a young one, this good girl has a right to call me ſo by the name of father.—Haſn't ſhe, Grey?—why, my Lord, this is the very parſon I told you of!—
(taking Cecilia's arm under his)
and now, young Sir, what do you ſay to your uncle's freaks?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Say, Sir, that had you ten thouſand ſuch I would go through a patriarchal ſervitude, in hopes of Cecilia's hand for my reward.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: And, had I ten millions of money, and this only girl, thou ſhould'ſt have her, and that, too, for thy noble freedom.—And what ſays my Cecilia to her father's firſt gift?

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhment and pleaſure leave me hardly power to ſay, that a diſobedience to you, ſir, would only double my fault: nor to worſhip that Heav'n, which has led me through ſuch a trial to ſuch a reward!—take all I have left myſelf to give you, Woodville, in my hand— (Woodville kiſſes firſt her hand, and then herſelf)

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.p: Now, let me die, my darling child! ſince I have ſeen thee, once more, innocent and happy.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: And now, kiſs me, my Cecilia!—kiſs me!—od, Miſs Mortimer ſhall kiſs me too, for loving my poor girl here!—kiſs me, all of you, old and young!—men, women and children!—od, I am ſo overjoy'd, I dread the conſequences.—D'ye hear, there?—fetch me a ſurgeon and a bottle of wine!—I muſt both empty and fill my veins on this occaſion—zooks, I could find in my heart to friſk it merrily in defiance of the gout, and take that curſed vixen below, whoever ſhe is, for my partner!

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: Methinks all ſeem rewarded, but my poor Sophia here? and her protection of Cecilia deſerves the higheſt recompence: but whenever, my dear, you can preſent me the huſband of your choice, I will preſent him with a fortune fit for my daughter.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Protect Cecilia! od! ſhe is a good girl, and a charming girl, and I honour the very tip of her feathers now!—if ſhe could but fancy our Charles,
I'd throw in ſomething pretty on his ſide, I promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Mor.
sp.p: Frankneſs is the faſhion.—What would you ſay, Sir, and you, my Lord, if I had fancied your Charles ſo much, as to make him mine already?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Hey day! more diſcov'ries! how's this, boy?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Even ſo, Sir, indeed.

sp.speaker: L. Glen.
sp.p: It completes my ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Od, brother! who'd have thought you in the right all the while—we'll never ſeparate again, by the Lord Harry! but knock down our Welch friend's old houſe; and raiſe him one on the ruins, large enough to contain the whole family of us, where he ſhall reign ſole ſov'reign over all our future little Woodvilles and Cecilias.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Oppreſſed with wonder, pleaſure, gratitude, I muſt endeavour to forgive myſelf, when heav'n thus graciouſly proves its forgiveneſs, in allying me to ev'ry human being my heart diſtinguiſhes.

sp.speaker: Grey.
sp.p: Yes, my Cecilia, you may believe him, who never gave you a bad leſſon, that you are now moſt truly entitled to eſteem; ſince it requires a far greater exertion to ſtop your courſe down the hill of vice, than to toil ſlowly up toward virtue.
